messages: 18151e5e9243e2881d9a6b076b183957 (04:24): The MS-6585 (MSI 648 Max) motherboard seems to only support 512Mb memory using 400MHz DDR modules, or 2Gb memory using 333MHz DDR modules or 3Gb using 266MHz DDR modules.  Which is the best module solution?
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (04:29): i would just stick with 3x512
ad4599b85caeb58a9c0d611527c4a1d2 (04:29): the mobo supports DDR
ad4599b85caeb58a9c0d611527c4a1d2 (04:29): so you need an even number of sticks
ad4599b85caeb58a9c0d611527c4a1d2 (04:29): matching pairs
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (04:30): dual memory channels require matched pairs
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (04:30): and i do not think that board supports dual channels.
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (04:30): DDR works within each module to double its effective bandwidth. number of modules does not effect that.
18151e5e9243e2881d9a6b076b183957 (04:33): the mobo has 3 slots though, not 2 or 4
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (04:33): how does this FSB stepping work?
18151e5e9243e2881d9a6b076b183957 (04:33): What I'd like to know is which solution provides the most memory?
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (04:35): yes, 3 1gb sticks is probably more expensive
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (04:35): how does this MHz stepping work?
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (04:35): does it explain how/why/when it does it?
18151e5e9243e2881d9a6b076b183957 (04:36): I haven't found any explanation
18151e5e9243e2881d9a6b076b183957 (04:37): http://www.msi.com.tw/program/products/mainboard/mbd/pro_mbd_detail.php?UID=355
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (04:40): i would expect that board to handle 3 1gb modules of 400MHz ddr just fine
18151e5e9243e2881d9a6b076b183957 (04:41): http://www.ec.kingston.com/ecom/configurator_new/modelsinfo.asp?id=3&SysID=13498
bab5d1733bee9596ea76260696246f5e (04:41): one of the hard drives in the school server died about four hours ago
bab5d1733bee9596ea76260696246f5e (04:41): now it's finally back up
18151e5e9243e2881d9a6b076b183957 (04:41): no, only two 256mb (single bank) modules or one 512mb (double bank) module at 400MHz
bab5d1733bee9596ea76260696246f5e (04:41): silly md being so hard to figure out
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (04:41): necro: where do you see it say that?
18151e5e9243e2881d9a6b076b183957 (04:41): http://www.ec.kingston.com/ecom/configurator_new/modelsinfo.asp?id=3&SysID=13498
bab5d1733bee9596ea76260696246f5e (04:41): the array was dirty AND degraded, so md choked on it
bab5d1733bee9596ea76260696246f5e (04:42): which is kind of stupid
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (04:42): wtf, are all intel boards that crippled?!
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (04:43): Supports only 2 Banks at 400MHz using two 256MB (single bank) modules or one 512MB (double bank) module.
bab5d1733bee9596ea76260696246f5e (04:43): and the internet is particularly useless in this respect
bab5d1733bee9596ea76260696246f5e (04:44): ton of help if you want to set up md, but very little if you need to actually *recover* from an error
bab5d1733bee9596ea76260696246f5e (04:45): mdadm --verbose --verbose --assemble /dev/md1 /dev/hda2 /dev/hdg3 --force
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (04:45): unless you believe your system usage habits could limp along on only 512MB
da785166998520d8584f0a2e6a8aacf2 (04:45): i would set the system up for ddr 333
